Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: I need to figure out which events belong to the same case. Since there's no explicit case ID, I have to look at the attributes and the sequence to group them.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: First, I remember that in process mining, cases are typically sequences of activities related to a single instance, like a patient's journey. So each case should have a logical flow of activities that make sense for one patient.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Looking at the events, each has timestamp, activity, resource, department, patient_age, patient_gender, and additional_info. The key here is that for a single case, the patient's age and gender should stay the same throughout all their events. Because each patient has a fixed age and gender. So if two events have different ages or genders, they must be different cases.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Let me check the data. Let's list all the events with their age and gender: ... So looking at age and gender, they seem to repeat. For example, age 45 male appears in events 1,4,7,12,15. Age 62 female in 2,5,8,10,11,14,17. Age 28 male in 3,6,9,13,16,18. So that's three different groups based on age and gender.

Name: Counterfactual Reasoning - PE
Text: But wait, maybe there's more than one case for same age/gender? But probably not, because each patient is unique. But maybe the same age and gender could be different patients, but in this dataset, maybe each age/gender combo is a separate case.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Let's take the first group: age 45, male. Events 1,4,7,12,15. ... That seems like a logical flow. ... Another group: age 62, female. Events 2,5,8,10,11,14,17. ... That also seems logical. ... Third group: age 28, male. Events 3,6,9,13,16,18. ... That makes sense.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Similarly, the 45M case: register in ER, triage, X-ray (Radiology), then doctor consultation in ER, discharge. So X-ray is part of the ER process, but done in Radiology department. That's normal. The 62F case: register ER, triage, lab test requested in ER, then lab completed in Lab department, then doctor consultation in ER, prescription, discharge. Yes, that all makes sense.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Let me check the timestamps to see if the order makes sense for each case. Case 1 (45M): Event 1: 08:05:13 4: 08:10:50 7: 08:15:42 12: 08:23:10 15: 08:30:05 Yes, each subsequent event is later. So the sequence is in order. ... So each case's events are in chronological order when grouped together.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So there are three cases. Each case is defined by unique patient age and gender. Because even if two patients have same age and gender, but in this dataset, since all the events for same age/gender are consecutive in their own sequence ... the key is that each case's activities are for the same patient. Therefore, the three groups are: Case A: age 45, male Case B: age 62, female Case C: age 28, male
